awd_titl_txt: Investigating the Effects of Socioscientific Argumentation Development on Student Academic Success
awd_abstract_narration:
Bethune-Cookman University is examining the effects of socioscientific argumentation learning and development on student success in STEM. The overarching purpose of the research is to investigate how to produce STEM graduates with argumentation expertise to address ill-structured problems that require scientific, evidence-based reasoning to inform decisions. The researchers will structure an intervention around units of biology and environmental science courses focused on scientific issues and conduct a three-phase research study. The Phase I pilot will determine the current argumentation level of STEM students and analyze the pilot data to identify gaps in effective socioscientific argumentation development. In Phase II, the researchers will develop and adapt a socioscientific argumentation learning training system for students. Phase III will be an experimental study to investigate the effect of socioscientific argumentation training on student outcomes. The significance of the study is that the findings can be used to provide students with skills and competencies needed for graduate school or the STEM workforce; namely, evaluation of evidence, construction of arguments, and evaluation of competing arguments.

The researchers will use a quasi-experimental design to answer three research questions: 1) What socioscientific argumentation strategies do the students currently use? 2) What gaps exist in effective socioscientific argumentation? 3) Does socioscientific argumentation instruction influence student outcomes?  In Phase 1, they will use socioscientific issues at the nexus of food, energy, and water for questionnaires, written reports, and debates to collect data on students' decision-making process, tendency to engage in arguments, argumentation levels, and quality of argumentative structures. The researchers will use several rubrics and socioscientific argumentation models to analyze data collected in Phase 1. They then propose to conduct a pre- and post- comparison of the quality of arguments on socioscientific issues between intervention and comparison groups. Measures of student academic success will be assessed from the dimensions of academic achievement, career success, attainment of learning outcomes, persistence, acquisition of skills and competencies, and satisfaction. The research will produce information needed to develop intervention models for improving scientific argumentation skills development of STEM students.  

This project is supported by the Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) Broadening Participation Research in Education track. This program track supports ideas to create and study new models and innovations in STEM teaching and learning, investigate the underlying issues affecting the differential participation and success rates of students from underrepresented groups, and produce knowledge to inform STEM education practices and interventions.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Investigating the Effects of Socioscientific Argumentation Development on Student Academic Success

The challenges of modern society including educational disparities, climate change, and pollution require the collaboration of scientists, educators, politicians, economists, and the public. Argumentation forms the basis of collaborative discussion which two parties can utilize to resolve an issue.

The major goal of the research project is to investigate how to produce Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) graduates with skills and competencies to address ill-structured problems that require scientific, evidence-based reasoning to inform decisions.

This Broadening Participation Research (BPR) in STEM Education project links to a Targeted Infusion Project at Bethune-Cookman University titled "Developing Quantitative Expertise in the Undergraduate Biology Curriculum (QEUBiC) [1434186 (PI - Isokpehi RD; Co-PIs - Wollenberg Valero KC; Congdon E. 08/15/2014 - 07/31/2018). The QEUBiC curriculum enhancement framework is for biology students to develop the scientific literacy to provide biology-based solutions to societal issues of food, energy, health, and environment in an era of Big Data challenges.

Thus, the QEUBiC curriculum is addressing the importance of connecting science to matters of social importance also termed Socioscientific Issues. Scientific Literacy entails the ability to make informed decisions, analyze, synthesize and evaluate varied sources of data and information, use moral reasoning to attend sensibly to ethical issues, and understand the complexity of connections inherent in socioscientific issues.

The Broadening Participation Research (BPR) project expands this scientific literacy research at Bethune-Cookman University (B-CU) beyond the biology curriculum. The Socioscientific Issues (SSI) framework for scientific literacy development require students to engage in dialogue, discussion, debate, and argumentation.

Argumentation (argumentative discourse) in scientific topics is defined as the connection between claims and data through justifications or the evaluation of knowledge claims in light of evidence, either empirical or theoretical. A key reason for this research is that argumentation will empower students from distinguishing claims made on scientific grounds from those based solely on tradition and authority.  

The project outcomes are divided into four distinct areas:

A. Socioscientific Argumentation Development System at Bethune-Cookman University 

The socioscientific argumentation development system consist of a three-stage learning process of initiation (obtaining knowledge on elements of argumentation), development (practice evaluation of evidence, construction of arguments, and evaluation of competing arguments) and reinforcement (perform skills and competencies of socioscientific argumentation).
The 2019 Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19) pandemic presented multiple societal dimensions including vaccinations, masks, antivirals, food shortages and physical distancing.
B. Development of Visual Literacy Intervention for Critical Thinking on Sustainability Issues
The intervention was designed to test and improve visual literacy at three levels: (1) elementary-identifying values; (2) intermediate -identifying trends; and (3) advanced-using the data to make projections or conclusions. Students demonstrated a significant difference in their ability to answer elementary and advanced visual literacy questions in both course sections in the pre-test and post-test. 
More details at Krejci SE, Ramroop-Butts S, Torres HN, Isokpehi RD. Visual literacy intervention for improving undergraduate student critical thinking of global sustainability issues. Sustainability. 2020 Jan;12(23):10209. https://doi.org/10.3390/su122310209

C. Institutional Quality Enhancement Planning for Student Success 

The project findings are being leveraged in the development and piloting of a university-wide Quality Enhancement Plan for Student Success at Bethune-Cookman University. All academic disciplines through faculty development will have access to the curricula innovations for teaching argumentation and reasoning. 

More details at https://cookman.libguides.com/ld.php?content_id=63763736

D. Dissemination of Project Activities

A 3-minute video on the socioscientific argumentation intervention is available at https://stemforall2020.videohall.com/presentations/1764 as part of the 2020 STEM FOR ALL VIDEO SHOWCASE.

Two Webinars (one hour each) on Socioscientific Argumentation Development are available on STEM Central website:

https://stem-central.net/web/course-and-curriculum-improvement/blogs/-/blogs/

Evidence and/or artifacts for every area are included as part of the Project Outcome Report.


Last Modified: 10/29/2021
Modified by: Hector N Torres

Images (1 of )
  • How to produce STEM graduates with argumentation expertise to address-ill structured problems that required scientific, evidence-based reasoning to inform decisions.
    Dr. Hector N. Torres, Dr. Sarah Krejci, Dr. Raphael Isokpehi and Dr. Dana Zeidler
    Copyrighted
    Raphael D Isokpehi
    Investigating the Effects of Socioscientific Argumentation Development on Student Academic Success
  • The challenges of modern society including climate change, pollution, and educational disparities require the collaboration of scientists, educators, politicians, economists, and the public. Argumentation forms the basis of collaborative discussion which two parties can utilize to resolve an issue.
    Dr. Hector N. Torres. Dr. Sarah Krejci and Dr. Raphael Isokpehi
    Copyrighted
    Raphael D Isokpehi
    Utilizing argument driven inquiry with scaffolding to improve socioscientific argumentation and academic success in nonmajor Environmental Science
  • Workshop provided for faculty and students on SSI/ADI. The WORKSHOP AGENDA included; Workshop Objectives; Key Terms Identification; Main Topic A: Socioscientific Issues (ADI) Framework; Main Topic B: Argument Driven Inquiry (ADI); Discussion/Q&A and Workshop Assessment Survey and Adjournment.
    Dr. Hector N. Torres and Dr. Dana Zeidler
    Copyrighted
    Raphael D Isokpehi
    Cross Discipline Socioscientific Issues and Perspective Taking
  • The Quality Enhancement Plan (QEP) is an educational institution's five-year blueprint for improving the quality and efficiency of student learning as required by SACSCOC for reaffirmation. For the period 2022-2027, Bethune-Cookman has chosen Reimagining Innovations in Student Experiential Learning
    Dr. Hector N. Torres
    Copyrighted
    Raphael D Isokpehi
    Quality Enhancement Plan (QEP)
  • Argumentation Driven Inquiry introduced by the NSF project award 1623371 is a focus of the Bethune-Cookman University Quality Enhancement Plan. The QEP will enhance the following 21st century competencies: reasoning and argumentation; teamwork and collaboration, and flexibility and adaptability.
    Dr. Hector N. Torres, Dr. Sarah Krejci, Dr. Raphael Isokpehi and Dr. Dana Zeidler
    Copyrighted
    Raphael D Isokpehi
    Socioscientific Argumentation for Student Academic Success
  • The 2019 Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19) is recognized as socioscientific issue with relevance at multiple academic levels as well as informal learning. Students have opportunity to prepare, practice and perform skills and competencies for argumentation.
    Dr. Sarah Krejci, Dr. Raphael Isokpehi, and Dr. Hector Torres
    Creative Commons
    Raphael D Isokpehi
    Virtual Socioscientific Argumentation Development using COVID-19 as Socioscientific Issue
